body: precheckin green
I'll merge this tomorrow if there are no objections.
Much better! Now to review.

Hello @jhuynh1,

Thanks for pointing this out, I totally forgot about the new serialization stuff... the `TypeUtils` class, and its inner classes as well, are only used as utility classes so they shouldn't be persisted nor sent through the wire at any point, meaning that they shouldn't be serialized and, thus, it should be safe to add them to `geode-core/out/test/resources/org/apache/geode/codeAnalysis/excludedClasses.txt`. I'll submit the changes shortly.
Thanks.

commit c1b21c036d4a425b39ecb3fb1024657fd3332a13 (HEAD -> develop, origin/develop)
Author: Bruce Schuchardt <bschuchardt@pivotal.io>
Date:   Fri Feb 2 13:07:38 2018 -0800

Good work on this PR.

For future reference, this is not the correct way to test for backward compatibility.  The code in the old client is 1.5 code.  Shoving 1.3 into Version.CURRENT is making the client pretend to be a 1.3 client and servers will serialize messages accordingly.  A change in handshake serialization on my "develop" branch for 1.5 caused this test to throw an OutOfMemoryError and blew up my pre-checkin run.

The correct way to create an old-version client is to use Host.getVM(versionName, vmNumber), as in
Host.getHost(0).getVM("130", 4)

Then it will actually be running with 1.3 code.

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Writing+Backward-compatibility+DUnit+tests

I'm fixing up the test and will make it a parameterized test running against all available old-versions.

Bah!  Don't know how I missed those, when I was exactly looking for those.

Good catch.
@jinmeiliao That did cross my mind.  Definitely good to be sure, though.

Someone else had addressed the same problem in a different file by just skipping the log message when it would use `null`, so I chose consistency.

Testing notes:

- log4j 2.10.0 seems to break servlet session replication tests.
- fast-classpath-scanner gives different results than previously.
- shiro-core now depends on other shiro libraries (all ASL 2.0).
- swagger adds these libs:
   - byte-buddy (ASL)
   - javassist (MPL / LGPL / ASL)
   - reflections (WTFPL // approved by ASF)

precheckin green

Hey @PurelyApplied,

Thanks for notifying me about these problems, I'll keep them in mind for future changes!.
Just one comment from my side..

> Inner classes should not be interspersed with methods. Put them either at the beginning or the end of the class, whichever is more appropriate for readability.

My preferred style is to put them wherever they seem to make most sense, and for this particular case I've just added them before the single group of methods that actually uses the inner class. That said, there are several inner classes interspersed with methods through the source code (not only within test classes), so I'm guessing this is just a preference instead of a standardized source code style, is that right?. If it is, shouldn't we _enforce_ this rule through the **com.diffplug.gradle.spotless** to avoid this kind of code being merged and fail fast?. Or even add the specific guideline to the [Code Style Guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Code+Style+Guide)?.
Just my two cents.
Cheers!
clean precheckin
To be clear, you're not intending to update log4j and fast-classpath-scanner now?

Correct.  log4j2 2.10.0 has a problem with Tomcat which shows up in our session replication tests.  

The new version of fast-classpath-scanner has different behavior which means we'll need to change our usage if we want to update.

precheckin green

@jujoramos 
Yeah, I should've used less absolute language about the stylistic things.  As you linked, neither our adoption of Google's Java Style nor our minor differences with it mention anything about inner classes.

For my philosophically two cents, I think that if a class is meant to be a level of abstraction, it should be abstracted *away* and not be in the guts of implementation details.  Putting it at the bottom makes sense to me in the same way that `public` methods belong at the top of a class.  But yes, it's more a personal preference and style than any standardization.

Then again, I'd love to have a longer conversation about adopting and adhering to a stricter code style (and correcting those numerous cases where the codebase currently falls short).  And I do have some changed I'd like to make to `spotless` as it is.  I'll probably send something out on the dev list in the next week or so.  Definitely chime in there.

@upthewaterspout the mark/reset methods will only fail if the stream doesn't support these methods.  I added them so we can rewind to the previous line when we hit the next stack dump in the input stream.  The end of the dump is either EOF or the beginning of another dump.

If you clean up `SingletonValue` you should update `geode-core/src/main/resources/org/apache/geode/internal/sanctioned-geode-core-serializables.txt:org/apache/geode/internal/util/SingletonValue$ValueState,false` too.

@dschneider-pivotal @nreich I added dataPolicy in RegionShortcut just so that I can see more visually what dataPolicy each RegionShortcut corresponds to. It doesn't change any api. But let me know if you see any issues. Thanks!

Precheckin green.

@jinmeiliao @kirklund 
I think that removing the `LogWrapper` is a good idea, but probably beyond the scope of this ticket.  Passing the `cache` in to preserve behavior seems like a good idea to me until we can write some good tests surrounding logging behavior, and which point we can then remove the `LogWrapper` in favor of the `LogService`.

For what it's worth, some manual testing shows minor but probably trivial differences in replacing the `LogWrapper` with the `LogService` logger.  In a locator-side `GfshCommand` execution, the `LogWrapper` includes in the logs:
```
open-jolly-cat.log:[info 2018/02/27 10:05:03.546 PST open-jolly-cat <RMI TCP Connection(1)-10.118.33.214> tid=0x53] (tid=83 msgId=0) PRHOMBERG testy test
```
where the `LogService` contained
```
bang-tender-pot.log:[info 2018/02/27 10:11:49.649 PST bang-tender-pot <RMI TCP Connection(2)-10.118.33.214> tid=0x56] PRHOMBERG testy test
```

I don't know what the `tid` and `msgId` info are, nevermind whether or not it is being meaningfully consumed, but there it is.

Due to git weirdness, closing (and then will reopen) this PR.

merged to develop in 0afb75bbaef7dfba7bfba70d8de0617c30db99c2

Some of my own concerns:

* I'm bad at names.  It had been `CacheCommandContext` earlier.
* Is there a more appropriate package for `CacheMembers` than `o.a.g.management.internal.cli`?  I had had it in `o.a.g.m.i.c.commands`, only because that's where `GfshCommand` lives, but backed it up one since it's not really `command` material.
* I have mixed feelings about anonymous classes.  I more strongly want `GfshCommand` to extend `CacheMembers`, rather than make `CacheMembers` a proper class that accepts an `InternalCache` as input, and then have `GfshCommand` delegate its methods to that class.

Thoughts?

I feel more inclined to put all the methods in CacheMembers to GfshCommand and have it only available for the commands to use. From the changeset, it seems only commands are using CacheMembers now except BeanUtilFunc.java, and the method DistributedMember getDistributedMemberByNameOrId(String memberNameOrId) is only used twice. We should make that method available through the DistributedSystemBridge itself and get rid of the method all at all.

LGTM

OT:  

@pivotal-jbarrett and I were discussing the complexity of the current gfsh process management:
- invoking `gfsh.sh` to launch a jvm running `gfsh`
- invoking `start XXX` command to fork a jvm running a geode process
- dealing with i/o redirection, status, and pids

What if users could just launch geode with `java -jar start server ...`?  gfsh would still be useful for *cluster* management, but wouldn't need to be in the business of process management.  Am I missing something?  We could still provide scripts to encode the jvm options we think are important.
The initial commit comment says `Under JDK 9, this logic does work`. Should that be `does *not* work` and, if so, shouldn't we be fixing that problem too?
Hi @bschuchardt , is this PR ok to merge now.
I'd be in favor of removing anything that relies on the attach API. It's not going to exist everywhere so let's just keep things simple.
